identificationModule.officialTitle: Intensive Pediatric Group Intervention in a Curricularly-embedded Pro-bono Clinic

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The purpose of the Mizzou emPOWER program is to meet the curricular needs of entry-level doctorate of physical therapy students by providing them the real-world experience of implementing recent evidence surrounding physical therapy dosing for children with cerebral palsy (CP) for power, strength, and gait interventions while meeting an unmet community need.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Beginning in Fall 2024, the investigators will recruit 6 children with CP, Gross Motor Function Classification System Levels I-III, ages 7-17 years old, to participate in the program. Two students will be assigned to each participant, rotating every 4 weeks due to the structure of the pro-bono clinic. A total of 3 faculty members will supervise. The group will meet for 2 hours, 2 times per week for 15 weeks. Each session will include a 10-minute game-based warm-up, 45 minutes of gait interventions to include treadmill and overground walking as well as other aerobic activities, 45 minutes of resistance training (power and strength training as appropriate for their individual goals), and a 10-minute cool-down incorporating yoga and breathing activities. Participant assessments will be completed during the first week, 7th week, and 15th week. Other programmatic assessments will include students' written reflections on their experiences providing this program, caregiver satisfaction surveys, and participant and caregiver interviews.

armGroups.label: PhysZou emPOWER
armGroups.description: Strength, power, and gait-based intervention for kids with cerebral palsy is embedded within a curricular pro-bono student physical therapy clinic. The group will meet for 2 hours, 2 times per week for 15 weeks.
interventionNames: Other: PhysZou emPOWER: a strength, power, and gait intervention group physical therapy program for children with CP

interventions.name: PhysZou emPOWER: a strength, power, and gait intervention group physical therapy program for children with CP
interventions.description: Each session will include a 10-minute game-based warm-up, 45 minutes of gait interventions to include treadmill and overground walking as well as other aerobic activities, 45 minutes of resistance training (power and strength training as appropriate for their individual goals), and a 10-minute cool-down incorporating yoga and breathing activities. To ensure participants are exercising at the appropriate level of intensity, 1 repetition maximum measures will be used to determine the appropriate levels of resistance and heart rate monitors will be worn.

primaryOutcomes.description: Particpants will complete strength testing of hip/knee extensors and plantarflexor muscle groups using a leg press, using 1 Rep max testing protocols, as outlined in Pontiff and moreau, 2022. (PMID 35960137)
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: Walking speed test of 10 meter distance, completed in both conditions of self selected speed and fast gait speed
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: Assessment of lower extremity power
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: Functional measure of how quickly child can climb up and down 1 flight of stairs
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: This is a clinical assessment of lower extremity strength, in which investigators count the number of repetitions of sit to stands completed in 30 seconds.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: This is a clinical assessment of lower extremity strength, in which investigators count the number of repetitions of half kneel to stand complete correctly in a 30 second time period.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: This is a clinical assessment of lower extremity strength, in which investigators count the number of repetitions of lateral step ups completed in 30 seconds on a standard size 6 inch step.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: This is a criterion referenced measure of gross motor function and is valid and reliable for children with cerebral palsy. It evaluates motor skills that are typical for normal development. Dimensions D and E will be utilized, as these 2 sections assess the overall gross motor function in direct relation to standing, walking, running, and jumping.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: Evidence-based outcome measure designed to capture a client's self-perception of performance in goals they determine before intervention. The measurement focuses on self-care, leisure activities, and productivity. The participant rates their performance and their satisfaction with their performance on a scale from 1-10, with 1 indicating poor performance and low satisfaction, while 10 indicates very good performance and high satisfaction.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.measure: Standing balance with eyes closed standing on firm surface
primaryOutcomes.description: Participants will stand on a force plate with eyes closed. Postural control information is obtained from the investigators and the force plate tracks the center of pressure of the participant.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.measure: Standing balance with eyes closed standing on firm surface
primaryOutcomes.description: Joint kinematics (movement strategies) obtained while eyes closed standing on firm surface
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: Walking speed is obtained form spatial sensor
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: Stride length obtained from spatial sensor
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: speed of walking will be obtained from spatial sensor while completing appropriate/salient cognitive dual task
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: stride length will be obtained from spatial sensor while completing appropriate/salient cognitive dual task
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: time to complete and knee joint kinematics obtained from spatial sensor
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: knee joint kinematics obtained from spatial sensor while the participant steps down from a 6 inch curb step
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: Production of power will be obtained from force plate and spatial sensor
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: Assessment of knee joint kinematics during jumping will be obtained from force plate and spatial sensor
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

primaryOutcomes.description: measurement of upper extremity reaching reaction
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before PT intervention begins (week 1), midpoint of program (Week 7), and last week of program (week 15).

secondaryOutcomes.description: Semi-structured interviews will provide researchers with the perspective of the children and caregivers who participated in this novel program.
Open ended surveys will provide researchers with the perspective of the children and caregivers who participated in this novel program.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Perspectives of Doctor of Physical Therapy Students
secondaryOutcomes.description: Open ended surveys will provide researchers and faculty with the perspective of the learning opportunity from the students

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Ambulatory children 7-17 years old, children who are participating in emPOWER program
* GMFCS Levels I-III
* Able to follow 2-3 step directions
* English Speaking

Exclusion Criteria:

* Orthopedic surgery in the past year
* Significant visual impairment
* Significant hearing impairment
eligibilityModule.studyPopulation: Ambulatory children aged 7-17 years old with Cerebral Palsy (GMFMCS Levels I-III), participating in PhysZou emPOWER program.

Hedgecock JB, Harris NM, Rapport MJ. Changing Practice: Clinical Application of Resistance Training Evidence for Children With Cerebral Palsy. Pediatr Phys Ther. 2023 Jul 1;35(3):367-376. doi: 10.1097/PEP.0000000000001023.

Oudenhoven LM, van Vulpen LF, Dallmeijer AJ, de Groot S, Buizer AI, van der Krogt MM. Effects of functional power training on gait kinematics in children with cerebral palsy. Gait Posture. 2019 Sep;73:168-172. doi: 10.1016/j.gaitpost.2019.06.023. Epub 2019 Jul 16.

van Vulpen LF, de Groot S, Rameckers E, Becher JG, Dallmeijer AJ. Improved Walking Capacity and Muscle Strength After Functional Power-Training in Young Children With Cerebral Palsy. Neurorehabil Neural Repair. 2017 Sep;31(9):827-841. doi: 10.1177/1545968317723750. Epub 2017 Aug 8.
